title: I do hope that democracy’s for sale: Freedom doesn’t come for free
text:
What price democracy? Even as protests, which often turn violent, erupt in Hong Kong over the curtailing of civil liberties by Beijing, not a few in this country are given to wondering how fleet of foot in economic terms might have been the lumbering Indian elephant had it been unburdened by the populist weight of democracy, as the authoritarian Chinese dragon has been. Such ironic double-takes only go to show the home truth behind the homily that the grass is often greener on the other side of the ideological fence.

Both democracy, and its dictatorial antithesis, come with price tags, incalculably different though these may be. Now, however, a reserve price has been put on democracy, or least on an avatar of it which exists in the virtual world of cyberspace. A domain called Democracy.com, set up some years ago by an American anti-capitalism activist is up for sale by auction later this month, and is expected to go under the hammer for anything upward of $300,000.

The company which is setting up the auction for cyber democracy seems confident of coming up trumps, in the plural if not in the singular with a capital `T’. Cashing in on a form of government which supposedly is of the people, by the people, and for the people, might, however, evoke among those who hold democracy to be priceless. Oscar Wilde’s definition of a cynic as a person who knows the price of everything and the value of nothing.
